title: spell.yaml
description: Defines a spell. You can use `fluence spell new` command to generate a template for new spell

aquaFilePath.description: Path to Aqua file which contains an Aqua function that you want to use as a spell

function.description: Name of the Aqua function that you want to use as a spell

initArgs.description: A map of Aqua function arguments names as keys and arguments values as values. They will be passed to the spell function and will be stored in the key-value storage for this particular spell.

clock.description: Trigger the spell execution periodically. If you want to disable this property by overriding it in fluence.yaml - pass empty config for it like this: `clock: {}`

periodSec.description: How often the spell will be executed. If set to 0, the spell will be executed only once. If this value not provided at all - the spell will never be executed

startTimestamp.description: An ISO timestamp when the periodic execution should start. If this property or `startDelaySec` not specified, periodic execution will start immediately. If it is set to 0 - the spell will never be executed

endTimestamp.description: An ISO timestamp when the periodic execution should end. If this property or `endDelaySec` not specified, periodic execution will never end. If it is in the past at the moment of spell creation on Rust peer - the spell will never be executed

startDelaySec.description: How long to wait before the first execution in seconds. If this property or `startTimestamp` not specified, periodic execution will start immediately. WARNING! Currently your computer's clock is used to determine a final timestamp that is sent to the server. This property conflicts with `startTimestamp`. You can specify only one of them

endDelaySec.description: How long to wait before the last execution in seconds. If this property or `endTimestamp` not specified, periodic execution will never end. WARNING! Currently your computer's clock is used to determine a final timestamp that is sent to the server. If it is in the past at the moment of spell creation - the spell will never be executed. This property conflicts with `endTimestamp`. You can specify only one of them
